comment._content: Is that a gun in his pocket?  The Playboy of the Mae Western World !

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: And the men are sitting and standing around as usual?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I was expecting some female chauvinist to fall into that trap, that's because the photo was taken at the house and the men did their work in the fields or on the sea!!!!!  Tsk, Tsk!

comment.author: 38866414@N00
comment._content: This must have been what life was like for my Mother and her parents in rural Ireland. A lot of information in this photo!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/shamous] Perhaps it was like this for your family... Where were they from?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 38866414@N00
comment._content: They are from Westport, Co. Mayo. Grandma had twelve children of which three of them were triplets...My Mother was one of the triplets. All the children survived. My aunt told me that they would wake up in the morning and ask themselves "How will we survive today?"  She came to America in 1948, but has never forgotten her heritage. Your site gives me a feel on how things were in her day, and I'm grateful for that.  Thank you !

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/shamous] You're more than welcome! And amazing (for those days) that the triplets made it.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 98209876@N08
comment._content: I don't care how poor we are, we always have some sort of an animal in the family.
